metadata.title: Chemical grafting of nano-SiO2 onto graphene oxide via thiol-ene click chemistry and its effect on the interfacial and mechanical properties of GO/epoxy composites

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Composites Science and Technology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/compscitech
Chemical grafting of nano-SiO2 onto graphene oxide via thiol-ene click chemistry and its effect on the interfacial and mechanical properties of GO/epoxy composites Mingye Wanga, Lichun Maa,*, Longlong Shia, Peifeng Fenga, Xuejie Wanga, Yingying Zhua, Guangshun Wub, Guojun Songa,** a Institute of Polymer Materials, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University, Qingdao, 266071, China b School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Ludong University, Yantai, 264025, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Graphene Epoxy resin Click reaction Mechanical properties
A B S T R A C T
A facile and rapid come close to the manufacture of advanced epoxy nanocomposites by grafting of nano-silicon dioxide (nano-SiO2) onto the graphene oxide (GO) through thiol-ene click reaction was reported. The correlations between surface modification, morphology, dispersion/exfoliation, interfacial interaction of sheets and the corresponding mechanical properties of the composites were methodically explored. It appeared that nano-SiO2 have been grafted onto GO via covalent bonding successfully, which effectively improved the interface compatibility and dispersion in epoxy matrix. The reinforcing mechanisms has been also elaborated. It is demonstrated that the tensile strength and elastic modulus for filler with 0.1 wt% GO-SiO2/epoxy composites increased by 32.18% and 22.86% compared to neat epoxy, respectively. It is believed that the simplistic and effectual method may provide a novel and promising strengthen design strategy for next‐generation advanced nanocomposite structures.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Epoxy resins are typical thermoset plastic with eminent mechanical properties, chemical stability, corrosion resistance and insulation behavior that can be widely applicable to various applications like coatings, adhesives, electronic packaging, automotive and the aerospace industry [1,2]. However, the low toughness and inherent brittleness extremely limit its applications in many special fields [3]. To this end, researchers have committed to increase the toughness and strength of epoxy resins. One method is to introduce nanofillers (like inorganic nanoparticles [4], nanowires [5], carbon nanotubes [6], etc.) into epoxy resins, which are regarded as a promising nanomaterial for enhancing the polymer composites properties. Unlike traditional fillers, the nano-size effects of nanoparticles can show higher interfacial interactions with matrix that could be afforded unique performances. Graphene, a new two-dimensional material, has become one of the most research hotspots in scientific community owing to its incomparable thermal conductivity, mechanical and electrical properties [7–10]. As an ideal nanofiller, it can be incorporated in epoxy matrix to enhance the mechanical and thermal properties. But graphene sheets
are liable to irreversible severe aggregation in epoxy matrix owing to ππ stacking effects and van der Waals force, which result in a weak interaction between graphene sheets and epoxy resin [11,12]. Generally, the dispersion and the interfacial adhesion of graphene determine the properties of epoxy composites to a great degree. For purpose of improving the dispersibility and interfacial compatibility in epoxy matrix, chemical functionalization of graphene is an effective measure. Graphene oxide(GO)is a derivative of graphene, compared with graphene, the surface is severely oxidized which result in many reactive groups like hydroxyl, carboxyl and epoxy groups [13–15]. These plenty of suitable reactive sites not only make chemical modification of graphene possible but also improve the interface interaction with polymer. B. Ramezanzadeh et al. [16] have investigated the grafted polyisocyanate (PI) onto GO sheets for the mechanical properties of GO-PI/polyurethane composites, the results showed that GO-PI/polyurethane composites enhanced the mechanical properties after addition of 0.1 wt %. Liu et al. [17] have grafted poly (oxyalkylene) amines (D400 and D2000) onto GO sheets and noticed that the mechanical properties and thermal properties improved distinctly. Meanwhile, the tensile strength of 0.1 wt% D400-GO/epoxy and D2000-GO/epoxy composites

increased by 23.5% and 21.6%, respectively. Compared to the chemical functionalization of graphene with small molecules or macromolecules, the introduction of nanoparticles on the GO surface is also a promising variant. Low-cost nano-silicon dioxide (nano-SiO2) has many excellent properties, such as high strength, high toughness, corrosion resistance and high temperature resistance, and it has been proved to be a promising functional filler [18]. The supporting of nano-SiO2 on GO sheets could not only prevent the agglomeration of graphene and nanoparticles themselves, but also exert their own advantages to achieve special properties. Accordingly, in order to make use of the advantages of GO and SiO2 nanofillers, the properties of GOSiO2 hybrids/polymer composites was studied. For example, Jiang et al. [19] have prepared functionalized GO by silanized silica nanoparticle and investigated the toughening effects of GO-SiO2 on epoxy matrix, and revealed that GO-SiO2 hybrids have better dispersibility and interaction in epoxy matrix. Generally, GO-SiO2 hybrids can be prepared by sol-gel method, in situ grafting and electrostatic assembly [20–23], which can effectively promote the synergy between graphene and SiO2, but the high production cost, long time, pollution, etc. limited its application in various fields. In recent years, thiol-ene click chemistry has been favored by scientists for its simple reaction conditions, fast speed, high yield, environmental friendliness [24,25]. It had been applied to various research fields, such as preparation of macromolecules, surface modification of materials, etc. In addition, compared with other modifications of GO, thiol-ene click reaction is easy to operate, the mild reaction conditions, and insensitive to oxygen [26]. Therefore, it is a very promising technique to introduce nano-SiO2 onto GO surface. Unfortunately, as far as we know, there has little literature on the grafting of nano-SiO2 onto GO surface by thiol-ene click reaction. In this paper, to take full advantage of GO and nano-SiO2, thiol-ene click reaction was adopted to functionalize GO surface by grafting nano-SiO2. Then GO-SiO2 was introduced into epoxy resin as a reinforcing filler to enhance the mechanical properties of epoxy resin. The microstructure of GO-SiO2 was confirmed by FTIR, XPS, XRD, TEM and SEM. The dispersion, interfacial and mechanical properties as well as the enhancement mechanism of GO-SiO2 hybrids/epoxy composites was also extensively investigated. It is expected that the combination of SiO2 particles with GO sheets could formed a special three-dimensional point-plane structure, which could have better dispersion and interact with epoxy matrix, and improve the mechanical properties of epoxy composites.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Graphite powder was obtained from Qingdao Tianhe Co. Ltd. Epoxy resin (E−51) with epoxy value=0.48–0.54 was used as matrix in composite. Liquid aromatic amine type epoxy resin hardener H-256 was provided by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co. Ltd. SiO2 nanoparticles (diameter= 30 nm), 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxy silane (KH-590) and γ-methacryloxypropyltrimethoxy silane (KH-570) and initiator 2,2′‐azobis(2‐methylpropionitrile) (AIBN) were supplied by Aladdin Chemical Reagent Corporation. Sodium nitrate (NaNO3), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), hydrogen peroxide (30% H2O2), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and absolute ethanol was purchased from Tianjin, China. Concentrated sulfuric acid (98% H2SO4), acetic acid and hydrochloric acid (37% HCl) was provided by Laiyang Economic and Technological Development Zone Fine Chemical Plant.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of KH-590 functionalized GO
sections.text:
GO sheets were prepared by graphite powder through modified Hummers’ method in our previous work [27]. To obtain –SH groups on GO surface, the GO was functionalized by KH-590. In a typical method,
0.2 g GO was added into a mixed solution of absolute ethanol and deionized water and dispersed by ultrasonication for 1 h. Then 2mL KH-590 was added into the dispersions and the PH was adjusted to 5 with acetic acid. The mixture was refluxed at 78 °C for 6 h to make sure the completion of the silylation reaction. After that, the mixture was washed for five times by absolute ethanol and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The product obtained was named GO-KH-590.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of KH-570 functionalized SiO2
sections.text: For functionalizing SiO2, 0.2 g SiO2 was added into the mix solution of absolute ethanol and deionized water by ultrasonication for 1 h. Next 2mL KH-570 was added into the dispersions and adjusted PH to 5 with acetic acid. The ternary mixture was refluxed at 78 °C for 6 h. After that, the mixture was washed for five times by absolute ethanol to remove excess KH-570, and then dried at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain vinyl groupsfunctionalized SiO2, which was named SiO2–KH-570.

sections.heading: 2.4. Grafting nano-SiO2 onto GO surface via thiol-ene click chemistry
sections.text: The grafting nano-SiO2 onto GO surface were conducted by thiolene click reaction, as shown in Fig. 1. AIBN was used as thermal initiator for the click reaction. Firstly, 0.1 g GO-KH-590 and 0.1 g SiO2–KH-570 were dissolved into 100mL DMF and sonicated for 1 h. Then, AIBN was dispersed in the mixture and stirred at 80 °C for 4 h. Finally, the mixture was washed by a large amount of absolute ethanol to remove ungrafted substance and dried at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain GOSiO2 hybrids.

sections.heading: 2.5. Fabrication of epoxy composites
sections.text: The GO-SiO2/epoxy composites were prepared by solution blending, and the mass fraction of GO-SiO2 in epoxy was 0.1 wt %. The fabrication of composites was as follows: A mount of GO-SiO2 hybrids were added into acetone and sonicated for 1 h. The epoxy resins were poured into the mixture and sonicated for 1 h, then the mixture was evaporated to remove acetone. Afterwards a stoichiometric amount of hardener (H-256) was added into the mixture and stirred evenly, then degassed in vacuum oven until removing any trapped bubbles by vacuum. After that the mixture was dumped to the mold cured at 100 °C for 2 h and 150 °C for 4 h. For comparison, the same procedure for prepare of neat epoxy, GO/epoxy composites were fabricated.

sections.heading: 2.6. Characterizations and measurements
sections.text: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, NEXUS) was conducted to analyze the functional groups on the surface of graphene and hybrid materials, which recorded in the wavelength range of 500 cm−14000 cm−1 and wavenumber at 4 cm−1 resolution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 220i-XL) was used to characterize the surface chemical composition and elemental content of sample. The chemical composition of sample was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD, DX-2700), the scanning range was from 5° to 45°with scan rate of 3°·min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7800F) was carried out to the surface morphology of samples. The dispersity of GO in matrix were observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, G2F30) and optical microscopy. Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA, DTG60H) was carried out to investigate the thermal stability of the GOSiO2 hybrids, measured at a heating rate of 10°·min−1 at 30°C–800 °C under N2 atmosphere. The tensile and flexural tests were examined on universal testing machine(Al-7000) with cross-head speed of 2mmmin−1 and gauge length of 60mm, in addition, the specimen dimensions was 80mm (long)× 10mm (wide)× 4mm (thick). According to GB/T2567-2008, the impact properties of unnotched composites were evaluated by impact testing machine (XJJ-50). Each specimen was tested for 5 times to calculate the average value.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of GO-SiO2 hybrids
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of SiO2, SiO2–KH-570, GO, GO-KH-590 and GOSiO2 were shown in Fig. 2a. The characteristic bands at 1077 cm−1 and 804 cm−1 in SiO2 spectrum were ascribed to the stretching and bending vibration of Si–O–Si. In addition, the park at 948 cm−1 was attributed to Si–OH stretching vibration [28]. Compared to SiO2, two new bands at 1706 cm−1 and 1628 cm−1 in the spectrum of SiO2–KH-570 appeared, which represented the stretching vibration band of C=O and C=C. In the spectrum of GO, the significant peak exhibited as follows: O–H stretching vibration at 3100 cm−1, C=O carbonyl stretching vibration at 1716 cm−1, C=C phenol ring stretching vibration at 1608 cm−1 and C–O–C at 1039 cm−1 attributed to the oxirane moieties of GO [29]. After modified with KH-590, some addition peaks at 2957 cm−1 and 2860 cm−1 originated from asymmetric vibration of –CH2. In addition, the peak at 1038 cm−1 was observed, which was ascribed to Si–O–C stretching vibration. Also, the stretching vibrations of –SH absorbance peak was found at 2560 cm−1. In the spectrum of GO-SiO2, the disappearance of –SH peak in 2560 cm−1, and the appearance of Si–O–Si (1098 cm−1 and 803 cm−1) and Si–OH (957 cm−1) indicated that the reaction between GO and SiO2 have been successfully
proceeded by thiol-ene click reaction. Fig. 2b showed the XRD spectra of GO, GO-KH-590, GO-SiO2. GO presented a narrow and strong diffraction peak at 10.86°, which corresponded to a layer spacing of about 0.81 nm [30]. After modified with KH-590, a broader and weaker diffraction peak in comparison with GO was appeared at 10.02°, which corresponded to a layer spacing of about 0.87 nm. The increase in layer spacing was due to the grafting of KH590 on the GO surface. In the case of GO-SiO2, a weak broad diffraction peak was observed around at 23°, which revealed that the amorphous SiO2 nanoparticles was adhered onto the GO surface [31]. Meanwhile, the characteristic diffraction peak of GO was significantly weakened, which indicated that GO-SiO2 was stacked together in a loose manner. The illustration showed that GO and GO-SiO2 powder had the same quality. It can be seen that the volume of GO-SiO2 was larger than GO owing to the attachment of nano-SiO2 onto GO layers. This covalently grafting of SiO2 onto GO surface was conducive to prevent the restack of graphene layers and enhance the dispersion of GO in epoxy matrix. The XPS was carried out to further determine the surface chemical composition of GO, GO-KH-590, GO-SiO2, the obtained spectrum was shown in Fig. 3 and Table 1. In Fig. 3a, GO consisted of carbon and oxygen element, which was 69.9% and 30.1%, respectively. The characteristic peaks of silicon (3.85%) and sulfur (2.65%) appeared in GOKH-590, indicating that KH-590 was grafted onto GO surface successful.
For GO-SiO2, the content of silicon and oxygen element greatly increased, and the carbon and sulfur element reduced, indicating that the GO surface was covered by nano-SiO2. The high-resolution C1s and S2p spectrum were to estimate the function groups, as shown in Fig. 3b–f. The C1s peak of GO showed many functional groups including C=C, C–C, C–O, C=O and O–C=O at 284.5 eV, 285.6 eV, 286.6 eV, 288.2 eV and 289.2 eV, respectively [32,33]. For GO-KH-590 (Fig. 3c), two new peaks for C–Si (283.5 eV) and C–S (285.9 eV) appeared. Furthermore, the intensity of C–O
obvious decreased due to the nucleophilic substitution on hydroxyl groups. For GO-SiO2, the intensity of C–Si increased and C–S decreased compared with GO-KH-590, which indicated that nano-SiO2 was successfully introduced onto GO surface. The S2p peak of GO-KH-590 in Fig. 3e was divided into spin-orbit coupling of S2p1/2 and S2p3/2 (with a typical energy difference of 1.2 eV), which represented the existence of –SH group [34]. It was noteworthy that the intensity of R-S-C peak increased in Fig. 3f. Meanwhile, the H–S–C peak did not disappeared which implied that –SH groups were not reacted with vinyl groups completely, while the S–O peak might ascribe to unwanted oxidation byproducts [35]. This result further confirmed that the covalent bonds are formed between GO and nano-SiO2 via thiol-ene click reaction. The TGA thermal analysis curve of SiO2, SiO2–KH-570, GO, GO-KH590, GO-SiO2 were shown in Fig. 4. SiO2 showed extremely high thermal stability with char residues of 94.73% at 800 °C. In contrast, the thermal stability of SiO2–KH-570 decreased compared to SiO2, and exhibited 9.02% loss at 800 °C. This can be attributed to evaporation of water and decomposition of silane molecules. According to Fig. 4b, the thermal decomposition loss of GO mainly occurred in three temperature
intervals: The weight loss from 30 to 140 °C was owing to the evaporation of adsorbed water. The interval from 140 to 330 °C was owing to the decomposition of some oxygen-containing functional groups on the graphene surface or edge, which was the main cause of GO weight loss. The loss of weight between 330 and 800 °C may be due to the disintegrating of the carbon skeleton in GO [36]. In the case of GO-KH590, the main pyrolysis in 140–250 °C was owing to some oxygencontaining groups, and in 250–500 °C was owing to the decomposition of silane molecules. Compared with GO, the char residues have risen to 55.9%. For GO-SiO2, the decomposition behavior was similar to GOKH-590 with char residue of 68.6%, but its degradation rate was notable lower than GO-KH-590. This was mainly due to the delayed degradation and good thermal stability of SiO2 covered onto GO surface, which meant that the thermal stability of GO was improved by functionalization with SiO2 [37].

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphology of GO-SiO2 hybrids
sections.text:
The structural morphology and surface characteristics of GO derivate were analyzed by SEM, as shown in Fig. 5. SEM image of GO (Fig. 5a) showed an irregular flaky with two-dimensional structure, which had lots of creases and folding [38]. On the surface of GO-SiO2
(Fig. 5b), some spherical aggregated SiO2 was covered on the GO surface. Meanwhile, the GO surface was rough and uneven due to the deposition of SiO2, which indicated that GO might be successfully functionalized by SiO2 through thiol-ene click reaction. TEM was used to observe the morphologic characteristics of GO and GO-SiO2. The exfoliated GO in Fig. 5c exhibited a transparent structure with many small wrinkles and large specific surface area [39]. For GOSiO2, the stripped single layer of GO was covered with a layer of SiO2 nanoparticles, which could provide strong interfacial interaction with polar epoxy matrix. Similar results were reported by Jiang et al. and Azimi in TEM micrographs of silica-coated GO layers [19,36].

sections.heading: 3.3. Dispersion of GO-SiO2 hybrids in solvent and epoxy matrix
sections.text:
The dispersion stability of GO and GO-SiO2 prepared in acetone at the concentration of 2mgml−1 were observed after ultrasonic treatment and standing for different times, as shown in Fig. 6a-b. After sonication and standing for 5min, GO and GO-SiO2 could be well dispersed in acetone. However, after standing for 24 h, GO appeared to precipitate under the bottle, exhibiting the changed color from black to brown. The presence of SiO2 had a great effect on dispersion of GO in acetone, GO-SiO2 produced only partial sedimentation and could
maintain stability, which was because that the adhesion of nano-SiO2 to GO surface created a space barrier between the GO sheets, and it was difficult to form agglomeration, so that the particles can be well dispersed in acetone, thereby could improve the dispersibility in epoxy matrix [40]. The dispersion and interfacial quality of epoxy composites were examined by optical microscopy and TEM. As shown in Fig. 6c, the filler with 0.1 wt% GO showed many clusters in epoxy matrix (red circle), similar results were shown in TEM, GO in Fig. 6e showed a tendency to accumulate in the epoxy matrix because of the high specific surface area [32]. By comparison, GO-SiO2 (Fig. 6d) was well dispersed in epoxy matrix and it was difficult to see some large agglomerates. In Fig. 6f, there were not stack structure of GO due to the presence of nano-SiO2. It seemed that GO-SiO2 could be dispersed and sticked firmly to epoxy matrix, and some GO-SiO2 was tightly embedded in epoxy matrix. This indicated that the grafting SiO2 contributed to the dispersion of GO and inhibiting re-aggregation, in addition, the improvement of the dispersibility and interfacial interaction in the epoxy matrix would contribute to improve the mechanical properties of epoxy composites.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanical properties of composites
sections.text:
Representative stress-strain curves for neat epoxy, GO/epoxy, SiO2/ epoxy and GO-SiO2/epoxy, along with the results of tensile and flexural testing, including tensile strength, elastic modulus, flexural strength
and modulus were listed in Fig. 7 and Table 2. The tensile strength and elastic modulus of GO/epoxy composite increased by 20.3% from 64.45 ± 2.81MPa to 77.52 ± 3.96MPa and 19.16% from 2.64 ± 0.10 GPa to 3.15 ± 0.15 GPa at 0.10 wt% GO loading compared with pure epoxy. The GO-SiO2/epoxy composite showed the highest tensile properties (85.18 ± 3.74MPa), increasing by 9.88% and 12.37% compared with that of GO/epoxy composite and nanoSiO2/epoxy composite. Similarly, the elastic modulus of GO-SiO2/ epoxy composite was also increased greatly. This illustrated that the reinforcement effect of GO-SiO2 on epoxy resin was more effective than GO or nano-SiO2. It is expected that the combination of SiO2 particles with GO sheets could formed a special three-dimensional point-plane structure, which could have better dispersion and interact with epoxy matrix, so that the load can be transferred from matrix to GO-SiO2 effectively and improved the mechanical properties. Moreover, similar results can be seen from flexural tests. The flexural strength and modulus of GO-SiO2/epoxy composites had more considerable improvement, the value was 149.45 ± 6.11MPa and 3.44 ± 0.16 GPa, increasing by 10.50% and 5.84% compared with the GO/epoxy composite. The impact tests were carried out to evaluate impact toughness of epoxy resins and their composites, as presented in Fig. 8. The introduction of 0.1 wt% GO and SiO2 into epoxy increased 22.49% and 27.93% for impact strength compared with neat epoxy. For GO-SiO2/ epoxy composites, the impact strength was 35.63 kJ/m2, increasing by 37.46% and 31.62% compared with that of GO/epoxy and SiO2/epoxy.
The grafting of nano-SiO2 onto GO surface may contribute to absorb more fracture energy and promote the stress transfer, which resulted in an improvement in impact strength. The improvement in mechanical properties of composites at lower filler loadings could be attributed to the following aspects: (1) The existence of SiO2 effectively inhibited the aggregation of GO and promoted the homogeneous dispersion in the matrix [41]. (2) The
mechanical engagement and covalent bond formation between epoxy matrix and GO-SiO2 sheets during the curing process was also responsible for the high tensile strength and elastic modulus of the GOSiO2/epoxy composite than pure epoxy and GO/epoxy samples [42]. (3) The special three-dimensional point-plane structure of GO-SiO2 could contribute to form a gradient modulus with the epoxy interface to transfer stress effectively. (4) Nano-SiO2 could also absorb fracture energy effectively during stress process which complicated the propagation path of force and leaded to synergistic reinforcement effect. The schematic diagram of stress transfer in nanocomposites was evidenced in Fig. 9a,b. To further estimate the dispersion and interface of GO-SiO2/epoxy composites nanocomposites, the cross-sectional fracture surfaces of the specimens after impact tests were observed by SEM. For 0.10wt% GO/ epoxy composites, there were many ripples structures on the fracture surface (Fig. 9c), which indicated the dispersion was uneven. In addition, there were some distinct gaps on the surface, signifying the poor interfacial adhesion between GO and epoxy matrix. Comparatively, the GO-SiO2/epoxy composites in Fig. 9d presented numerous smaller ripples with some ribbons and river lines on the cross-sectional fracture surface and some GO-SiO2 sheets appeared to well disperse in the epoxy matrix and no evident aggregation of sheets could be discovered. The formation of the ripples was accompanied by the generation of new fracture surfaces [43], and much more fracture energy would be

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this work, nano-SiO2 was grafted onto the GO surface by a thiolene click reaction, epoxy composites with both the as-produced GO and GO-SiO2 have been prepared and systematically investigated. The effective functionalization of GO with nano-SiO2 was attested to improve the compatibility and dispersion/exfoliation in epoxy resin. The mechanical properties tests revealed that the tensile and flexural strength of the GO-SiO2/epoxy composites significantly enhanced (by 9.88% and 10.50%) compared with the GO/epoxy composites. Meanwhile, the fracture toughness of GO-SiO2/epoxy composite improved effectively compared with that of neat epoxy (by 68.38%). The improvement was ascribed to the synergistic effect between the GO and SiO2 and the strong interaction with the resin matrix, which might effectively promote the load transferred being from the matrix to the GO-SiO2 sheets. Moreover, this project can be implemented easily and would have great potential for using as novel reinforcements in high performance nanocomposites.

metadata.abstractText: A facile and rapid come close to the manufacture of advanced epoxy nanocomposites by grafting of nano-silicon dioxide (nano-SiO2) onto the graphene oxide (GO) through thiol-ene click reaction was reported. The correlations between surface modification, morphology, dispersion/exfoliation, interfacial interaction of sheets and the corresponding mechanical properties of the composites were methodically explored. It appeared that nano-SiO2 have been grafted onto GO via covalent bonding successfully, which effectively improved the interface compatibility and dispersion in epoxy matrix. The reinforcing mechanisms has been also elaborated. It is demonstrated that the tensile strength and elastic modulus for filler with 0.1 wt% GO-SiO2/epoxy composites increased by 32.18% and 22.86% compared to neat epoxy, respectively. It is believed that the simplistic and effectual method may provide a novel and promising strengthen design strategy for next‐generation advanced nanocomposite structures.
